text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new era broad
album self-titled this band is a
norwegian rock outfit and their lineup
has been a bit of a revolving door since
they've been dropping releases in the
early 2000s right now they seem to be
functioning off of two core members who
collaborate with a bunch of different
musicians and noise makers and producers
to create their records and i heard an
EP of theirs that they dropped this year
called murderers art had three tracks on
it that were a bit of a mixed bag one
was a bit of a generic sludge metal
track one was an eight-minute noise
piece and another was sort of a noise
rock sludge metal combo that was 15
minutes long that had this sort of
hypnotic repetitious thunderous riff
approach not too unlike something swans
would do the EP caught my attention and
made me want to dive into the band's
other records look back into their
discography and I found that they came
out with an album this year and it's
like their sixth album and the sounds
that were on these albums was pretty
interesting in terms of just the
stylistic influence combinations we're
getting really heavy just BC sludge
metal and some elements of noise rock -
topped with some pretty eccentric vocals
that vary from these deep guttural
growls to these somewhat deadpan and
nasally ah moans and some very hellish
devilish snake-like whisper yes I liked
the variety that the vocals brought to
the table but still listening to these
records back to back I kind of got this
sense that era brah is the sort of band
that slowly fine Tunes its sound over
years upon years upon years rather than
coming through with something completely
radical and different with each new
release a lot like a bands such as high
on fire or The Melvins to a lesser
extent both of which I know I'm sure
her Arab rot takes at least a little bit
of influence from especially given that
they have worked with producers that
have created some of the best albums
from those bands people like Billy
Anderson as well as Steve Albini so the
years that this band has been spending
on the heavier side of things has
definitely resulted in them having a
very aggressive and ear catching sound I
wouldn't say the riffs on this LP are
thunderous like they're raining down
from the sky but they are pretty
aggressive and they do bring the rumble
the good of these characteristics is
that the album is loud as hell and that
the vocals are so weird and just off the
chart when it comes to the general
sludge metal sound that it's hard not to
get caught up in the eccentricity that
era brought brings to the table like the
very throaty snide whispers on the
opening track here that be nagged and if
Noah is yes then there is the song
throwing rocks at the devil which is
maybe my favorite track on this entire
LP has a fantastic guitar lead that
feels sort of influenced by Middle
Eastern music or music from the Eastern
Bloc and just these really hard-hitting
juts of guitar bass and drums just
syncopated and the vocals are all over
the map we have the very gruff growls
screaming this fantastic hook and then
shortly after we're getting these just
nasally moans coming back throwing rocks
at the devil it's a great track the bad
side of some of these characteristics
though is that the album is so boo me it
is so boo me man like especially the
drums and the drums do get to the point
where at times they swallow up the
vocals they swallow up the guitars and
kind of cover everything else that's
going on a lot like on the horns of the
devil grow or the vocals here can get so
weird that they feel a little silly and
and kind of take away from the
aggression of the song like blood on the
poet which oddly enough is sort of
inspired by a pretty odd French film of
a similar title I do like the wailing
lead guitars in the background on this
track but man do the vocals
dumb daughter go feel a little absurd
and not necessarily in like a flattering
way I do like that this band has some
odd lyrical concepts though and while
that's great it doesn't necessarily make
up for what I think is this album's
biggest issue and that is the riffs and
the song structures not really being
that interesting or adventurous I
actually think a majority of the riffs
on this album are pretty inconspicuous
and and standard when it comes to the
sludge metal sound especially the lead
single on here blood on bunny which is
maybe the most forgettable track on this
entire album just because of how bland
the Rivage is if the riffs are going to
be this overly simplistic I wish they
would come through with more tracks like
drawing down the moon where essentially
we we not only have these basic riffs
but we have a bunch of noises and and
sounds and sound play going on in the
background just kind of keep things
layered and engaging because this track
is not only sludgy but also psychedelic
and borderline disturbing with just how
chaotic it is the horns in the second
half of this track too
sound fantastic and make this song sound
really anthemic overall while I did like
the odd vocals and I thought the guitars
and the riffs on here were very visceral
I thought the recording was heavy and
there is some sound play on this
self-titled LP for sure this record does
have its eccentric moments but there
just wasn't enough of a structural or a
melodic or a musical appeal for much of
what's here to stick with me and I mean
we're talking about noise rock and
sludge metal on here when it comes to
melody I'm not looking for a whole ton
I'm feeling a decent strong six on this
thing transition if you've listened to
this album what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it Anthony Fantana arrow brought
self titled forever
